title: Can you give me examples of first, second, and third person point of view in writing? - Quora

response.answer_text: A school teacher of mine explained it thus; I am the first person, you are the second person, she is the third. So in writing (fiction) you would write in the first person : “as I left the house, I saw the evidence of the early morning rain, in the drops on the handrail as I walked down the front steps”Second would be “you hear birds and the sound of a car driven by someone in a hurry, you have to dodge quickly as you cross the road”.Third: “Sarah saw the bus coming around the corner as she hurried down the street and she knew that she would miss it by a few minutes” I just described one morning journey to work from the three different viewpoints.

I wouldn’t worry about second person. It isn’t really relevant in storytelling form. You may get the odd hint of it, but for the most part, stories are either written in first or third person. First person: I walked over to the bench and grabbed my coffee cup. Third person: He walked over to the bench and grabbed his coffee cup. Second person snippet (maintaining first person POV): I walked over to the bench and grabbed my coffee cup. You know how it is: we humans need our caffeine fix. The second person POV is the part where I say ‘you know how it is’ — second person is used to bring the reader in on the story and speak directly to them. Hope that’s all helpful. If you have any more questions, please reach out. I’m a professional editor and love to help how I can:-)

I sat under the ancient oak enjoying the warm summer breeze, that reached under my shirt, lifting the evaporating moisture from my skin. Without thought, I opened another button and plucked at the front of my shirt to let in more of that gentle caress. How do you justify to yourself, a whole afternoon; squandered, in a meadow, under an ancient oak. Are you proud of the time you have lost in such a trivial manner. Do you not weep for the time lost? He sat under the ancient Oak, resting, relaxing. Slithers of golden light reached him through the green canopy. Without conscious thought, he plucked at the front of his shirt, allowing the warm summer breeze to waft away the evaporating sweat from his skin. 1st, 2nd, 3rd pov

First person: I, Claudius, by Robert Graves. You can tell because it has “I” right there in the title. Claudius tells his own story. The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, by Mark Twain, would be another example. Third person: 1984, by George Orwell. Second person: This one is much harder, because writing fiction in second person is a gimmick, rarely used. Instead of a novel, I’ll use a song: The Hokey Pokey: “You put your right foot in, you take your right foot out…”

Thanks for the A2A. 1st person: I handed the sword to the master, and walked away. 2nd person: You handed the sword to the master, and walked away. 3rd person: He/she handed the sword to the master, and walked away.
